product_service_info.core_offering_description: Provides computer science education programs to primary schools across Australia.
product_service_info.unique_selling_proposition: Full solution for ICT education in schools, addressing mandatory curriculum changes and lack of school resources. Franchise model for scalability.

market_info.market_growth_rate: Driven by mandatory digital technologies curriculum

basic_metrics.price_points: 50 per student per term (5 per week)

questions_asked.raw_text: so Frank and Tracy you're looking for 632 000 for 15 of your company valuing your business is a cool 4.21 million dollars is that correct
questions_asked.response_text: that's correct

questions_asked.raw_text: so what age range are we talking about
questions_asked.response_text: steer of school to year 10 to you though we are working with United students now as well

questions_asked.raw_text: my daughter's grade two and I don't know whether it's necessary to teach a coding at grade two considering by the time she's in grade five what if she learns in grade two will be obsolete
questions_asked.response_text: as long as she's got those underlying skills then she'll grow with the technology it won't it won't be useless to us as well as that computational thinking and algorithmic thinking because employees in the future are going to require their employees to be clever and creative using technology and the younger we get them the more they'll learn and absorb over time

questions_asked.raw_text: so the education department are going to make coding mandatory in schools digital Technologies mandatory encoding's one aspect so surely that's going to destroy your business model then
questions_asked.response_text: no funnily enough it won't because what we actually do is we facilitate the the lessons to be able to be run because many schools just simply don't have the teaching staff the courseware all the hardware we're already in 150 schools and the level of Technology that's in schools at the moment is not great where and how are they going to get it into their budgets this business really it has a bit of a philanthropic aspect to it it's got a social impact which is every student should have access to these type of lessons so we brought the price down as far as possible

questions_asked.raw_text: each course is one 40-minute lesson for 10 weeks that's what each course is so one term long yeah so five dollars per student per week or 50 for the term
questions_asked.response_text: a young friend of mine does one a program at school and I don't know if it's your program are you in Scarborough yes yes we are well she's had incredible outcomes she adores it she's 12 12. and she does um she did 3D printing she did app development or something and she was doing gaming

questions_asked.raw_text: so tell us about the team how have you structured your team
questions_asked.response_text: well in in head office we have four executives and we're the ones who actually run the team we have about 20 staff that help facilitate the operation around the country and then we have those 19 franchisees

questions_asked.raw_text: so just to find your profit please Frank for this year we expect to make around five between 520 and 550 000 that's profit
questions_asked.response_text: net profit correct that's pretty good

questions_asked.raw_text: where are we going to be in three years time
questions_asked.response_text: in year three we're budgeted at current to make 5.4 million 5.4 million Top Line what's popping out the bottom now that's 5.4 million profits 5.4 million net profit before tax in year three

questions_asked.raw_text: how many franchises is that in three years then
questions_asked.response_text: uh in the three years well that would actually be mostly internally run territories to reach that 5.4 million right the capital we're asking for today will actually facilitate 14 more internal territories and they're much more profitable than the franchise model

questions_asked.raw_text: you reckon if you if we drop in 632 Grand 14 regions doubling the size of the business with this investment 19 to 14. pretty close about 14 very profitable regions because they're internally owned as opposed to 19 ones that are externally
questions_asked.response_text: look I think your space is clearly very appropriate there's no debate about that but you're only as good as your content I think you're going to make money but I think you've got a window of five to seven years and then you're going to be disrupted I think by different models so I wish you luck thank you

questions_asked.raw_text: what do you think apart from the cash Could you actually bring to us
questions_asked.response_text: not much I've had a lot of exposure to um coding over the years I I think it's integral to entrepreneurship so I've got a bit of a love affair with it I have a deep love affair with getting kids to be smarter and get engaged with tech

questions_asked.raw_text: Glenn are you going to counter that I don't think I don't think you need similar experience I think you need someone who knows how to scale up a business and and to get performance out of your franchisees from a remote headquarters you guys are expert in in doing this but what I'm going to assist is the coaching and the support in rolling out a network across Australia and then working out how to get performance out of that Network
questions_asked.response_text: I'll get him a lucky number 33. 632 000 for 33 percent

questions_asked.raw_text: so 33 from Glenn 30 from Steve what would you like to do
questions_asked.response_text: okay we really appreciate your offer and we think it's a really enticing thing to take but unfortunately that position of equity would be a little bit too much for us to give away at this point in a point in time Steve Tiara we only actually have authority from our other two shareholders to let a position go of up to 25 so we're wondering if there is something that can be done this would actually make you also the largest shareholder yeah wouldn't it and it'd be the first time that we've actually broken where we don't have equal shares from the business so it is a big step for us to let something like this go

questions_asked.raw_text: yep let's do it
questions_asked.response_text: congratulations thank you thank you so much looking forward to it congratulations thank you thank you so much I can't believe it

deal_breakers: Equity percentage too high initially for entrepreneurs

product_service_info.core_offering_description: Online antenatal classes and postnatal support for expecting parents.
product_service_info.unique_selling_proposition: Midwife-created, obstetrician-endorsed online platform offering comprehensive birth education from prenatal yoga to breastfeeding.

market_info.target_market_size: Expecting parents in Australia and potentially worldwide
market_info.market_growth_rate: Growing demand for online health and education resources

questions_asked.response_text: I'm very excited about some potential contracts that are coming up we have a 50 unit trial signed with one of Australia's largest banks to provide this to their employees in part of their corporate wellness package that corporate bank employs 55 000 employees oh very good we are also deep in discussion with hcf for birthbeat to be the preferred provider for their online platform

questions_asked.response_text: each couple receives a book it's posted in the mail they also get a little bag of goodie bags and then that's hand posted to them do you have a marketing expense above the line not yet what I have done is an online campaign with that is two videos those two videos one on Instagram one on Facebook one's been viewed 52 000 times one's being viewed 64 000 times so still struggling to to make the big leap from from nineteen thousand dollars to your two million dollar valuation

product_service_info.core_offering_description: Around school holiday programs in the workplace for working parents.
product_service_info.unique_selling_proposition: Convenient and innovative solution for school holiday childcare, offered as a corporate benefit to employees.

market_info.named_competitors: Traditional holiday programs, grandparent care, unpaid leave
market_info.market_growth_rate: Growing need for flexible childcare solutions for working parents

business_metrics.sales_numbers: Programs in 12 sites across 9 companies, 15 companies in pilot programs

questions_asked.raw_text: 375 000 bucks for 15 correct now we know each other don't we we do uh in all fairness you operate a uh Holiday Program from one co-working space in Brisbane River City labs and my daughter enjoys a living daylight yeah we love Livvy too awesome value and I love the service
questions_asked.response_text: so I'd like to clarify typically the age range for these kids is what primary school age five to twelve five to twelve and the people you're selling this to is usually the employer or are you selling it one-on-one to parents always the company we go through the HR so it's a business to business sale yes a YouTube the sales people at the moment we're everything all right okay so how many sites are you currently running programs in nine companies at 12 sites across Melbourne Sydney Brisbane and then we've got another 15 companies who are running pilot programs in the next two School holiday periods

questions_asked.raw_text: so tell me about these companies what's the minimum size to make them run profitably
questions_asked.response_text: so we have a minimum of 25 children per day at 80 a child and every kid after the first 25 that drop in is seriously better profit exactly absolutely so you valued your business at two and a half million yes so tell us about the revenue number yes because I'm sure they're going to just blow us away 2.5 ill will yeah

questions_asked.raw_text: so our first program which ran in July of 17. we've generated 20 000 in Revenue the following holidays we did 75 000 and the December January holidays just passed we did just over a hundred

key_events: Sharks went out due to implied concerns about financials and scalability
